summary: This document is an email chain from May 2021 between defense attorney Bobbi C. Sternheim and government prosecutors regarding scheduling the trial date for United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The defense argues for a November 8, 2021 start date, citing Maxwell's detention and holiday disruptions, while the prosecution proposes November 29, 2021. The correspondence reveals strategic scheduling conflicts and the defense's request for Maxwell's release on bail.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Sternheim
persons.context: Lead defense counsel corresponding with prosecutors to schedule Maxwell's trial, advocating for a November 8, 2021 start date and raising concerns about Maxwell's detention.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in case 20 Cr. 330 (AJN); her defense team argues her extended detention is harming her health and affects trial scheduling.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Copied on the defense team's email correspondence regarding trial scheduling.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Defense attorney mentioned as having a civil trial scheduled for December 13, 2021, which she would try to move to accommodate Maxwell's criminal trial.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Copied on the defense team's email correspondence regarding trial scheduling.

events.title: Proposed Defense Trial Start Date
events.description: The defense's preferred and "earliest" start date for Ghislaine Maxwell's trial, as argued in their April 22 letter-motion.

events.title: Proposed Government Trial Start Date
events.description: The prosecution's planned proposal to the court for the trial to begin on November 29, 2021, after considering witness and counsel availability.

events.title: Defense Letter-Motion for Continuance
events.description: The defense submitted a letter-motion (Docket 246) providing details to justify a request for a trial continuance to November 8, 2021.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The defense firmly requested a November 8, 2021 trial start date for Ghislaine Maxwell, citing her extended detention's 'deleterious effect on her health and well-being.'
The prosecution planned to propose a later trial start date of November 29, 2021, based on witness and counsel availability.
The defense stated that agreeing to Maxwell's release on bail would give them 'greater date flexibility' for scheduling the trial.

The defense argued that a late November start would disrupt Thanksgiving and potentially push the trial into the Christmas/New Year period, which could cast the defense case in a negative light with impatient jurors.
The email chain is part of a court-ordered conferral process, with a joint letter on the trial start date due on May 10, 2021.
